Acquisition: Life Cycle Cost
   
  Cost Impacts of Change (cont.)

A 1000 to 1 escalated cost ratio is not an insignificant number when we are talking about major systems costing billions of dollars and subsystems costing thousands or millions of dollars.

This is why life cycle costing is important in assessing the importance of the total cost of ownership. The majority of cost of ownership comes after the weapon system is being used in the inventory, not in its development and production phase.

To better understand these costs, enter a value into the text field in the diagram in the right column to calculate how much less a change would have cost had it been done earlier in the project. When you are finished, click the Forward button to continue.
